author: Corn√© van Zyl
title: Veteran playwright Mbongeni Ngema killed in accident
text:
Veteran playwright Mbongeni Ngema killed in accident
Sarafina producer Mbongeni Ngema was killed in a head-on accident near Mbizana on Wednesday evening. Here is the latest.
South Africa‚Äôs celebrated veteran theatre producer and musician, Mbongeni Ngema, was killed in a head-on accident near Mbizana on Wednesday evening.
BREAKING: VETERAN PLAYWRIGHT MBONGENI NGEMA KILLED IN ACCIDENT
Ngema is best known for his award-winning works, including Sarafina and Woza Albert, and hit songs such as Stimela sa se Zola.
According to reports, his family confirmed Ngema died in a statement on Wednesday evening.
ALSO READ:
Ryk Neethling‚Äôs sister Elsje passed away
NGEMA WAS KILLED IN A HEAD-ON ACCIDENT WHILE RETURNING FROM A FUNERAL
The 68-year-old musician was killed in a head-on accident while returning from attending a funeral in Lusikisiki, Eastern Cape.
‚ÄúIt is with heavy hearts that we announce the sudden passing of our beloved brother, father, husband, and patriot, Mbongeni Ngema. He was a passenger in the vehicle,‚Äù ‚Äì read the family‚Äôs statement.
ALSO READ:
Essential TIPS for driving on the highway in SA this holiday
HE WROTE THE WELL-KNOW MUSICAL SARAFINA
Born in 1955 in Verulam, KwaZulu-Natal, Ngema started his career as a theatre backing guitarist. He wrote the musical Sarafina! and co-wrote Woza Albert!, both of which won numerous awards.
Meanwhile, the
DA extended its heartfelt condolences to the loved ones of Ngema.
üïäÔ∏è | The DA extends its heartfelt condolences to the loved ones of legendary playwright, director, and musician Mbongeni Ngema.‚Äî Democratic Alliance (@Our_DA)
His tragic passing was confirmed in a statement by his family.
The award-winning musical, Sarafina, is one of his many works we‚Äôll forever embrace. üáøüá¶
[pic.twitter.com/3SzzR3thBI] [December 27, 2023] Minister of sports, arts and culture Zizi Kodwa also took to social media to express his shock.
I‚Äôm saddened to hear of the passing of Dr Mbongeni Ngema, one of South Africa‚Äôs great playwrights, directors, lyricists and composers. Dr Ngema‚Äôs internationally acclaimed work, from Sarafina to Stimela sase Zola, told distinctly South African stories and experiences. ‚Äì Zizi Kodwa

author: Li Yan
title: Natural scenery of Makehe primitive forest farm in Qinghai
text:
Aerial view of Makehenatural primitive forest in Banma County of Guoluo Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, northwest China's Qinghai Province, July 18, 2024. (Photo: China News Service/Ma Mingyan)
Situated in Sanjiangyuan National Nature Reserve with an average elevation of 3,600 meters, Makehe is the highest natural primitive forest in China, spanning Qinghai and Sichuan provinces.
Running through the forest, the Makehe River is one of the sources of the Dadu River, an important tributary of the Yangtze River.
Aerial view of Makehenatural primitive forest in Banma County of Guoluo Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, northwest China's Qinghai Province, July 18, 2024. (Photo: China News Service/Ma Mingyan)
Aerial view of Makehenatural primitive forest in Banma County of Guoluo Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, northwest China's Qinghai Province, July 18, 2024. (Photo: China News Service/Ma Mingyan)

author: AGENCY
title: Heal among trees: Forest therapy may be the escape you need when things get hard | The Star
text:
IT WAS a particularly chaotic time. As the war in the Middle East raged on, sparking relentless and horrific news headlines, a family member unexpectedly landed in the hospital. Hospital visits, doomscrolling and sleepless nights left me drained.
Perhaps that‚Äôs why an invitation to Forest Therapy ‚Äì something I might have previously dismissed as silly ‚Äì piqued my curiosity. I‚Äôd have tried anything to slow the incessant whirl of concerns in my head.
So one Saturday, I found myself laying in a cool, dewy patch of grass, early in the morning, in a lush palm grove at the Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens. The San Marino gardens weren‚Äôt yet open to the public and the grounds were eerily quiet but for the whooshing of leaves in the wind and the intermittent trilling of wild parrots.
The two-part class, US$60 (RM280) for members, US$80 (RM373) otherwise, led by forest therapy guide Debra Wilbur over consecutive Saturdays, promises to help participants ‚Äúdiscover pathways to restore emotional and physical well-being‚Äù during a guided nature immersion.
I was skeptical, but game. Seeking refuge in nature is hardly new and need not be exclusive ‚Äì why pay for it? And how was this therapy?
Turns out, Forest Therapy is a revamping of Forest Bathing, which became especially popular in the early days of the pandemic, when people sought refuge outdoors. The practice ‚Äì immersing oneself in nature, while utilising all the senses, to promote mindfulness and reap calming benefits ‚Äì grew out of the Japanese practice of shinrin-yoku, which was popularised in Japan in the ‚Äô80s.
Shinrin-yoku literally translates to ‚Äúforest bathing‚Äù ‚Äì but that presented a branding problem when the practice picked up steam, decades later, in the US, Wilbur explains. ‚ÄúPeople had concerns: ‚Äòdo I need to wear a bathing suit in the woods?‚Äô‚Äù she says. So the term Forest Therapy is now more commonly used, though the trained practitioner is considered more of a guide and the forest, the actual therapist.
Wilbur‚Äôs particular spin on the practice is heavily focused on ‚Äútherapeutic circle sharing,‚Äù in which participants reflect, in groups, as they go along. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs intimate. It‚Äôs powerful. You‚Äôll see,‚Äù she says, promising an experience that‚Äôs both communal and individualistic.
About 18 of us show up for Wilbur‚Äôs class that Saturday for different reasons, but we‚Äôre all seeking the same thing: to get out of our heads and into the moment. To feel grounded and to slow down.
Connect with environment
Wilbur ‚Äì who looks every bit the quintessential earth mother, with her salt-and-pepper hair pinned into a messy bun and wearing an aqua cape, cactus-print socks and hiking boots ‚Äì gives a short talk about the origins of forest bathing. Then she has us relax in the grass for a 30-minute, guided body scan meditation. Her voice is soft and soothing: ‚ÄúJust imagine that anything that‚Äôs clinging to you is falling off,‚Äù she coos. We close our eyes, or stare up at the blur of drifting clouds against the pale morning sky.
Afterward, Wilbur leads us on a series of walking ‚Äúinvitationals,‚Äù calling upon our senses to help us more deeply connect with the natural environment. At each new location, in a different part of the Huntington‚Äôs gardens, she asks us to move slowly and intentionally ‚Äì ‚Äúwander directionless‚Äù ‚Äì while focusing on her newest sensory request.
In the Palm Garden, we‚Äôre asked to open our mouths and taste the air on different parts of our tongue; in the Subtropical Garden, we‚Äôre asked to fondle the plants, to run our hands gently over their prickly spines or silky smooth leaves; at the Lily Ponds, filled with koi, ducks, turtles and a large snapping turtle, we‚Äôre invited to close our eyes and tune into the water‚Äôs ecosystem. Wilbur gives a talk about the globally circulating nature of water ‚Äúrunning underground and coming up and through us, sustaining us, flowing through the trees, their roots and leaves, evaporating into the sky and raining back down again, back through us.‚Äù
‚ÄúConceivably,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúthe tears we shed today may, a year from now, be part of a waterfall somewhere else. Water has a voice, a messaging system, that‚Äôs the invitation, to engage in that.‚Äù
Between locations, we‚Äôre reminded to walk at a snail‚Äôs pace, to feel the ground beneath our feet, the uneven surfaces and varying textures, spongy and responsive one minute, rock hard the next.
After each invitational, Wilbur gathers us back together with a shrieking bird call. ‚ÄúKuh-Kaw! Kuh-Kaw!,‚Äù she wails, neck craned backward and cupping her mouth.
We again form a circle to share our reflections. (Yes, snark creeps in: ‚ÄúHello, my name is Deb and I‚Äôm a whirlwind-aholic looking to slow down,‚Äù I joke to myself, before it‚Äôs my turn. But the collective earnestness is contagious.)
‚ÄúIt gave us the permission to feel and to be present and to stop,‚Äù says one participant.
‚ÄúIt was affirming, grounding,‚Äù adds another.
‚ÄúI noticed the geometry of the ferns adjacent to the chaotic vines,‚Äù notes another.
Sanctuary for space
The Huntington began expanding its wellness offerings in 2021. Wilbur‚Äôs class is part of its ‚ÄúRestore + Explore‚Äù series, which also includes twice-monthly tai chi classes. The program is an outgrowth of the pandemic, says public programmes and community engagement coordinator Joy Yamahata.
When nearly every cultural institution in Southern California was shuttered, the Huntington‚Äôs gardens, which reopened as of July 2020, provided a therapeutic escape.
‚ÄúPeople were scared, uneasy, things were shut down. So this was a response ‚Äì to use the gardens as a sanctuary for safety and peace,‚Äù Yamahata says. ‚ÄúSo we wanted to expand wellness in the garden.‚Äù
Wilbur, a visual artist and former art director for TV and films, was trained at the Prescott, Arizona-based Association of Nature & Forest Therapy, which offers training internationally.
She‚Äôs since led hundreds of sessions, over the last seven years, in various settings ‚Äì forests, but also the beach, in canyons and public gardens. She especially enjoys leading full moon sessions (‚Äúit‚Äôs like sharing secrets in the dark‚Äù) and sessions at proper institutions, such as the Huntington, before they are open to the public. It feels a little like ‚Äúbreaking the rules,‚Äù she says, not unlike ‚ÄúNight at the Museum,‚Äù where you‚Äôre encouraged to run free and touch the surroundings.
‚ÄúComing into formal gardens, people treat them very formally and carefully ‚Äì as well they should, not doing damage,‚Äù Wilbur says. ‚ÄúBut the invitation to step off the trail, to engage with plants by touching them, by smelling them, tasting the air ‚Äì it sort of loosens people‚Äôs ideas of what‚Äôs possible when they come into a more staid setting.‚Äù
At the end of our two-hour session, Wilbur gathers us in a dense and shady cypress grove, under a particularly unwieldy cedar tree, a snaggle of thick, twisty branches draping along the ground. She offers us freshly brewed tea made of lavender and a mixture of rose petals and rosehips. Then we each get a piece of black tourmaline, considered a so-called ‚Äúgrounding stone‚Äù that is said to offer protection.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all a reminder to take the time to slow down and log into your senses,‚Äù Wilbur says, before offering us bubble wands and a lesson on steadying the breath to calm the central nervous system.
‚ÄúStart to visualise letting stressors go ‚Äì pop! ‚Äì or send out beautiful wishes or intentions into the world,‚Äù she says.
So we do.
Tea party
As the grove fills with glistening bubbles popping in the trees, we enjoy one final circle share ‚Äì and then we mingle. It‚Äôs a tea party in the forest.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy to get all caught up in the news, in the fear, in what‚Äôs happening in our own lives,‚Äù says Shannon Leavitt, 60, a first time Forest Therapy participant. ‚ÄúJust the habit of having to do, and go fast, and get stuff done ‚Äì it‚Äôs a hamster wheel and it‚Äôs really nice to be reminded to step off and just be.‚Äù
Rhonda Waller, a 47-year-old psychotherapist from Eagle Rock who specialises in trauma, grief and loss, says the last several months, with the writers‚Äô and actors‚Äô strikes compounded by the war in the Middle East, has been especially rough for her clients. She recently discovered Forest Therapy ‚Äì today is her second class ‚Äì and she plans to bring her team of therapists to Wilbur‚Äôs next class so they can explore the practice as a healing modality.
‚ÄúI want them to have the grounding experience and to know this is a resource to be able to guide people, or themselves, for self-care,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a recalibration. It‚Äôs not just the lived experience, but hearing other people‚Äôs experiences that helps.‚Äù
Forest Therapy is hardly an antidote to world peace nor a cure-all for personal problems. But guided meditation in nature, supported by talk therapy, focused my attention, provided connection and calm.
It was an escape of sorts ‚Äì a salve after which everything felt brighter and more fragrant ‚Äì if just for a fleeting few hours. ‚Äì Los Angeles Times/Tribune News Service
Open Modal √ó

author: Duna M√°rquez
title: La DANA deja ya m√°s de 100 litros en la zona mallorquina de Ponent
text: Temporal La DANA deja ya m√°s de 100 litros en la zona mallorquina de Ponent Desde Emergencias piden a la ciudadan√≠a que extreme las precauciones Duna M√°rquez El temporal que [ha arrasado Valencia llega a Mallorca](/sociedad/2024/11/01/directo-ultima-hora-dana-azota-costa-mediterranea-sur-peninsula-110836402.html). Tras dejar precipitaciones intensas en Ibiza y Formentera, la DANA est√° descargando descargando con fuerza en parte de la isla.En la zona de Ponent se han registrado ya m√°s de 100 litros por metro cuadrado. Las intensas lluvias, adem√°s, han provocado inundaciones importantes en Calvi√†, donde la crecida del torrent de Galatz√≤ ha obligado adem√°s a cerrar al tr√°fico de un tramo de la Ma-101. Los municipios m√°s afectados por las lluvias son, de momento, Galilea, Puigpunyent, Andratx y Calvi√†. Precisamente en este √∫ltimo, se han producido algunas inundaciones, cortes de calles y desprendimientos en carreteras, que han obligado a movilizar a Polic√≠a Local y efectivos municipales. El ayuntamiento de Calvi√† ha informado del corte al tr√°fico de un tramo de la Ma-101, la carretera de Calvi√† a es Capdell√†, que se ha inundado por desbordamiento del torrente de Galatz√≥ y de varias v√≠as en Palmanova y Magaluf. La Polic√≠a Local y operarios municipales trabajan en las zonas afectadas. Se espera que en las pr√≥ximas horas la dana se desplace por gran parte de Mallorca, dejando importantes precipitaciones a su paso. M√°s de 50 litros por metro cuadrado en una hora La Agencia Estatal de Meteorolog√≠a recuerda que Mallorca se encuentra en alerta naranja por precipitaciones acumuladas de 50 litros por metro cuadrado en una hora, llegando a acumularse 120 litros por metro cuadrado en algunas zonas de la isla en pocas horas. Las lluvias se mantendr√°n hasta el s√°bado 2 de noviembre, alarg√°ndose el aviso naranja hasta primera hora de la ma√±ana. Con el avance de las horas la alerta desaparecer√°, pero las precipitaciones se mantendr√°n a lo largo del d√≠a. Parques, cementerios y pasos peatonales, cerrados El paso peatonal del paseo Mar√≠timo de Palma entre el Palacio de Congresos y el Parc de la Mar permanece cerrado este viernes por el mal tiempo. As√≠ lo ha informado el departamento de Carreteras del Consell de Mallorca en un mensaje en redes recogido por Europa Press. Cabe recordar que en Palma, desde las 14.00 horas de este viernes est√°n cerrados los parques y los cementerios. El Govern pide "m√°xima prudencia" Ante la emergencia meteorol√≥gica para este d√≠a de Tots Sants, el Govern balear ha reclamado ‚Äúm√°xima prudencia‚Äù a los ciudadanos ‚Äúlas pr√≥ximas horas y d√≠as‚Äù por la alerta naranja decretada. Se recomienda que se tomen precauciones y mantenerse informado de la predicci√≥n meteorol√≥gica m√°s actualizada. Las actividades habituales y al aire libre pueden verse alteradas. El Servicio de Emergencias 112 ha activado el √çndice de Gravedad 1 (IG1) del Plan Meteobal por lluvias y tormentas en Mallorca y Menorca. El paso peatonal del paseo Mar√≠timo de Palma entre el Palacio de Congresos y el Parc de la Mar permanece cerrado este viernes por el mal tiempo. As√≠ lo ha informado el departamento de Carreteras del Consell de Mallorca en un mensaje en redes recogido por Europa Press. Cabe recordar que en Palma, desde las 14.00 horas de este viernes est√°n cerrados los parques y los cementerios.
